results.title: The Repco-Brabham story
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson and Cine Service Production
results.brief_description: Briefly shows manufacture and testing of racing cars by the Brabham Racing Organisation in England, followed by views of the 1965 Tasman Series motor races in Australia and New Zealand, Jack Brabham and others competing in Brabham cars. Finally, manufacture of a new Repco engine in Australia is shown.

results.title: Headstart for Omar
results.creator_credit: Myrtle Winter-Chaumeny, United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: Omar was a boy when he fled with his parents from the family orange grove near Jaffa and joined 750,000 Palastinian Arab refugees streaming out of the new State of Israel. Ever since then Omar has waited and now lives in Qatar, where he works and bides his time. Like others of 1948, Omar waits for the world community to settle a long overdue account.

results.title: The People's land
results.creator_credit: Ralph Keene, Donald Taylor and Strand Films
results.brief_description: In Britain the National Trust has acqired a number of estates and areas of land of historical interest: they include ancient castles, such as the 14th century Bodian castle, a Chiltern village, the famous valley of Dovedale, a number of prehistoric stone circles, 14,000 acres of Westmorland countryside and an extensive area of downland in Sussex. These estates and landmarks are held in public trust forever.

results.title: The Rigid Heddle Frame
results.creator_credit: John Gray, Ken J. Widdowson and Educational Media
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Weaving”.
An instructional film on weaving for both beginners and more advanced weavers. In the rigid heddle frame, warp threads are passed through a slotted, wooden heddle instead of being attached to moving cords. Additional credits: photographer: Alan Grice ; script: Kay Donald ; editor: David Corke ; weaver and adviser: Erika Semler.

results.title: Tasmania's south west: a wilderness in question
results.creator_credit: Damon Smith, Rolf De Heer and AFTRS

video_links.name: Tasmania's south west: a wilderness in question

results.brief_description: Designed to increase public awareness of the nature of the South West Tasmanian wilderness and the threats facing it. Concentrates on the two main threats, namely the Hydro-Electric Commission’s damming and flooding of the wild rivers of the area for power development purposes and the extensive logging of the native forests by the Forestry Commission. Explores the issues at hand by interviews with leading figures on both sides of the struggle. Narrated by Ian McGarrity.

results.title: Nippers, chompers, grinders
results.creator_credit: Judy Nelson and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A film on dental hygiene for children ages 5-8. Janis, who refuses to brush her teeth, disappears down the plughole in order to escape that boring task. She meets three monsters, Nippers, Chompers and Grinders, each with specific tooth ailments and helps them overcome their disabilities. Voices: Valma Bolton, Colin Van Cao, Evelyn Krape, Stephen Radic, Claire Dobbin.

results.creator_credit: John Kingsford-Smith, Kingcroft Productions and National Trust
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “National Trust”.
Shows the oldest existing homestead in Victoria, Holly Green farm 1836. Also Rupertswood 1870, and Glen Eira homestead 1857. Written by Eileen Berry.

results.title: Frontline
results.creator_credit: David Bradbury, ABC, Australian Film Commission, Australian War Memorial, British Broadcasting Corporation and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
An account of the Vietnam War as seen through the camera of the late Australian war correspondent, Neil Davis. David Bradbury’s multi-award winning documentary also examines the ethical issues facing a man in the frontline who is not an active combatant.
Vietnam was a television war, a war said to have been lost in the lounge rooms of middle America, and not on the battlefield. This film explores the conflict, and Davis’ involvement in it, combining his original footage, comments and archival film. It includes the famous, historic footage of the fall of Saigon, which Davis was the only Western journalist to film.

Warning: some scenes may disturb.
